title: How to Make a Vegetable Omelette

steps.headline: Whisk 2 to 4 eggs in a bowl with salt and pepper.
steps.description: Crack 2 eggs into a bowl if you'd like a small omelette or use 4 eggs for a large one. Sprinkle salt and ground pepper over the eggs according to your taste. Then, use a whisk or fork to beat the eggs until they're combined. There's no need to beat the eggs until they're frothy, just mix them until the yolks are blended with the whites.

steps.headline: Melt the butter in a skillet over medium-low heat.
steps.description: Set an 8 in (20 cm) nonstick skillet on the stove if you're making a 2-egg omelette or use a 9 in (23 cm) skillet for an omelette with 3 or 4 eggs. Put 1 tablespoon (14 g) of unsalted butter in the skillet and heat it over medium-low until it melts and coats the bottom of the pan. Some people prefer to use a cast-iron skillet instead of nonstick. Use whichever skillet you're more comfortable cooking with.

steps.headline: Pour the eggs into the skillet and let them cook for 1 to 2 minutes.
steps.description: Avoid stirring the eggs once you pour them in the pan. You should see the edges of the eggs begin to turn white and set. If the eggs sizzle loudly when you pour them into the pan, the burner might be too high. Turn the burner down a little so the eggs can cook over gentle heat.

steps.headline: Loosen the edges of the omelet and cook the eggs for another 3 to 4 minutes.
steps.description: Take a silicone spatula and slowly run it around the edges of the skillet. Carefully tilt the skillet so liquid egg runs to the edges and begins to cook. Do this a few more times so all of the raw egg cooks and the omelette sets.Tip: If you're cooking a 3- or 4-egg omelette, you'll need to cook them a little longer than if you're only cooking 2 eggs. The eggs in the center of the skillet will be set, but a little soft. You can prep the veggies while the egg base of the omelette cooks.

steps.headline: Dice vegetables and sauté them separately for rich flavor.
steps.description:
Firm vegetables need to be chopped and sautéed in butter or oil in a separate skillet for a few minutes so they soften. This is important since they won't actually cook when you add them to the omelette. Chop the vegetables until they're about ⁄4 inch (0.64 cm) in size and cook them over medium heat just until they release a little moisture and become tender. You can sauté:Did You Know? Sautéeing the vegetables will release moisture and make the vegetables more flavorful. Bell peppers and hot peppers
Onions, shallots, and scallions
Asparagus
Mushrooms

steps.headline: Chop fresh spinach or tomatoes to add directly to the omelette.
steps.description: Cooking fresh spinach can make it become watery and heating tomatoes can cause them to lose flavor. Instead, trim the stems off of fresh spinach or chop ripe tomatoes into ⁄2 inch (1.3 cm) pieces. Then, they're ready for your omelette! If you're short on time, consider serving the omelette with fresh salsa.

steps.headline: Include cheese for a creamy flavor.
steps.description:
If you'd like to make your vegetable omelette even more filling, pick a cheese that works well with the vegetables you've chosen. Keep in mind that fresh or soft cheese melts easily into the eggs while hard cheese adds a sharp, noticeable flavor. Use your favorite cheese or try one of these cheese and vegetable combinations:
Goat cheese with herbs or shaved asparagus
Feta with diced tomatoes and fresh onions
Cheddar with sautéed onions and peppers
Brie with sautéed mushrooms

steps.headline: Mince fresh herbs to give the omelette a bright flavor.
steps.description:
It's easy to weigh down your omelette with creamy cheeses, sautéed vegetables, and leafy greens. To add a fresh taste, mince 1 to 2 tablespoons (2 to 4 g) of your favorite herb or use a combination. Consider using:
Chives
Parsley
Basil
Dill
Thyme
Cilantro

steps.headline: Place your fillings over 1/2 of the eggs in the skillet.
steps.description: Spread enough sautéed or fresh vegetables to cover 1/2 of the omelette. For example, you might only need 1/4 cup (55 g) of mushrooms with a few leafy greens. Add cheese if you like. Spreading the fillings over 1 side of the omelette will make it easier to flip since you won't have to worry about fillings falling out.

steps.headline: Fold 1/2 of the eggs over the filling to form the omelette.
steps.description: Use a flat spatula to loosen the edge along 1/2 of the omelette. Slide the spatula under the omelette and then quickly, but gently, fold the omelette over the fillings. Then, tilt the skillet to help the omelette slide onto your plate. If you're having trouble sliding the omelette, you may need to use the spatula to push it onto the plate.

steps.headline: Top the omelette with fresh vegetables.
steps.description: To add even more nutrients, flavor, and texture to your omelette, slice a ripe avocado and spread it over the top. You can also scatter baby greens, more herbs, or diced tomatoes to make the omelette even more colorful.Tip: If you don't have ripe avocado, spoon a little guacamole off to the side to get a similar flavor. If fresh corn is in season, cut the kernels off of the cob and sprinkle them over the omelette to give it a slightly sweet flavor.

steps.headline: Drizzle the omelette with sauce or sprinkle seasoning over it to add flavor.
steps.description: Take your omelette to the next level by topping it with some of your favorite sauces. You could season a bell pepper omelette with creole spices, for instance. Try adding pesto, which pairs well with mushrooms and onions or add a little sour cream or hot sauce to the veggie omelette. For a really hearty omelette, spoon some veggie chili to the side and put cheddar cheese with sour cream on top.

tyn: 8 or 9 in (20 or 23 cm) nonstick skillet
text:
Cooking the Egg Base Whisk 2 to 4 eggs in a bowl with salt and pepper. Crack 2 eggs into a bowl if you'd like a small omelette or use 4 eggs for a large one. Sprinkle salt and ground pepper over the eggs according to your taste. Then, use a whisk or fork to beat the eggs until they're combined. There's no need to beat the eggs until they're frothy, just mix them until the yolks are blended with the whites. Melt the butter in a skillet over medium-low heat. Set an 8 in (20 cm) nonstick skillet on the stove if you're making a 2-egg omelette or use a 9 in (23 cm) skillet for an omelette with 3 or 4 eggs. Put 1 tablespoon (14 g) of unsalted butter in the skillet and heat it over medium-low until it melts and coats the bottom of the pan. Some people prefer to use a cast-iron skillet instead of nonstick. Use whichever skillet you're more comfortable cooking with. Pour the eggs into the skillet and let them cook for 1 to 2 minutes. Avoid stirring the eggs once you pour them in the pan. You should see the edges of the eggs begin to turn white and set. If the eggs sizzle loudly when you pour them into the pan, the burner might be too high. Turn the burner down a little so the eggs can cook over gentle heat. Loosen the edges of the omelet and cook the eggs for another 3 to 4 minutes. Take a silicone spatula and slowly run it around the edges of the skillet. Carefully tilt the skillet so liquid egg runs to the edges and begins to cook. Do this a few more times so all of the raw egg cooks and the omelette sets.Tip: If you're cooking a 3- or 4-egg omelette, you'll need to cook them a little longer than if you're only cooking 2 eggs. The eggs in the center of the skillet will be set, but a little soft. You can prep the veggies while the egg base of the omelette cooks. Choosing a Vegetarian Filling Dice vegetables and sauté them separately for rich flavor. Firm vegetables need to be chopped and sautéed in butter or oil in a separate skillet for a few minutes so they soften. This is important since they won't actually cook when you add them to the omelette. Chop the vegetables until they're about ⁄4 inch (0.64 cm) in size and cook them over medium heat just until they release a little moisture and become tender. You can sauté:Did You Know? Sautéeing the vegetables will release moisture and make the vegetables more flavorful. Bell peppers and hot peppers
Onions, shallots, and scallions
Asparagus
Mushrooms Chop fresh spinach or tomatoes to add directly to the omelette. Cooking fresh spinach can make it become watery and heating tomatoes can cause them to lose flavor. Instead, trim the stems off of fresh spinach or chop ripe tomatoes into ⁄2 inch (1.3 cm) pieces. Then, they're ready for your omelette! If you're short on time, consider serving the omelette with fresh salsa. Include cheese for a creamy flavor. If you'd like to make your vegetable omelette even more filling, pick a cheese that works well with the vegetables you've chosen. Keep in mind that fresh or soft cheese melts easily into the eggs while hard cheese adds a sharp, noticeable flavor. Use your favorite cheese or try one of these cheese and vegetable combinations:
Goat cheese with herbs or shaved asparagus
Feta with diced tomatoes and fresh onions
Cheddar with sautéed onions and peppers
Brie with sautéed mushrooms Mince fresh herbs to give the omelette a bright flavor. It's easy to weigh down your omelette with creamy cheeses, sautéed vegetables, and leafy greens. To add a fresh taste, mince 1 to 2 tablespoons (2 to 4 g) of your favorite herb or use a combination. Consider using:
Chives
Parsley
Basil
Dill
Thyme
Cilantro Assembling and Serving the Omelette Place your fillings over 1/2 of the eggs in the skillet. Spread enough sautéed or fresh vegetables to cover 1/2 of the omelette. For example, you might only need 1/4 cup (55 g) of mushrooms with a few leafy greens. Add cheese if you like. Spreading the fillings over 1 side of the omelette will make it easier to flip since you won't have to worry about fillings falling out. Fold 1/2 of the eggs over the filling to form the omelette. Use a flat spatula to loosen the edge along 1/2 of the omelette. Slide the spatula under the omelette and then quickly, but gently, fold the omelette over the fillings. Then, tilt the skillet to help the omelette slide onto your plate. If you're having trouble sliding the omelette, you may need to use the spatula to push it onto the plate. Top the omelette with fresh vegetables. To add even more nutrients, flavor, and texture to your omelette, slice a ripe avocado and spread it over the top. You can also scatter baby greens, more herbs, or diced tomatoes to make the omelette even more colorful.Tip: If you don't have ripe avocado, spoon a little guacamole off to the side to get a similar flavor. If fresh corn is in season, cut the kernels off of the cob and sprinkle them over the omelette to give it a slightly sweet flavor. Drizzle the omelette with sauce or sprinkle seasoning over it to add flavor. Take your omelette to the next level by topping it with some of your favorite sauces. You could season a bell pepper omelette with creole spices, for instance. Try adding pesto, which pairs well with mushrooms and onions or add a little sour cream or hot sauce to the veggie omelette. For a really hearty omelette, spoon some veggie chili to the side and put cheddar cheese with sour cream on top.
sentences: Cooking the Egg Base Whisk 2 to 4 eggs in a bowl with salt and pepper.
Crack 2 eggs into a bowl if you'd like a small omelette or use 4 eggs for a large one.
Sprinkle salt and ground pepper over the eggs according to your taste.
Then, use a whisk or fork to beat the eggs until they're combined.
There's no need to beat the eggs until they're frothy, just mix them until the yolks are blended with the whites.
Melt the butter in a skillet over medium-low heat.
Set an 8 in (20 cm) nonstick skillet on the stove if you're making a 2-egg omelette or use a 9 in (23 cm) skillet for an omelette with 3 or 4 eggs.
Put 1 tablespoon (14 g) of unsalted butter in the skillet and heat it over medium-low until it melts and coats the bottom of the pan.
Some people prefer to use a cast-iron skillet instead of nonstick.
Use whichever skillet you're more comfortable cooking with.
Pour the eggs into the skillet and let them cook for 1 to 2 minutes.
Avoid stirring the eggs once you pour them in the pan.
You should see the edges of the eggs begin to turn white and set.
If the eggs sizzle loudly when you pour them into the pan, the burner might be too high.
Turn the burner down a little so the eggs can cook over gentle heat.
Loosen the edges of the omelet and cook the eggs for another 3 to 4 minutes.
Take a silicone spatula and slowly run it around the edges of the skillet.
Carefully tilt the skillet so liquid egg runs to the edges and begins to cook.
Do this a few more times so all of the raw egg cooks and the omelette sets.Tip: If you're cooking a 3- or 4-egg omelette, you'll need to cook them a little longer than if you're only cooking 2 eggs.
The eggs in the center of the skillet will be set, but a little soft.
You can prep the veggies while the egg base of the omelette cooks.
Choosing a Vegetarian Filling Dice vegetables and sauté them separately for rich flavor.
Firm vegetables need to be chopped and sautéed in butter or oil in a separate skillet for a few minutes so they soften.
This is important since they won't actually cook when you add them to the omelette.
Chop the vegetables until they're about ⁄4 inch (0.64 cm) in size and cook them over medium heat just until they release a little moisture and become tender.
You can sauté:Did You Know?
Sautéeing the vegetables will release moisture and make the vegetables more flavorful.

Bell peppers and hot peppers
Onions, shallots, and scallions
Asparagus
Mushrooms Chop fresh spinach or tomatoes to add directly to the omelette.
Cooking fresh spinach can make it become watery and heating tomatoes can cause them to lose flavor.
Instead, trim the stems off of fresh spinach or chop ripe tomatoes into ⁄2 inch (1.3 cm) pieces.
Then, they're ready for your omelette!
If you're short on time, consider serving the omelette with fresh salsa.
Include cheese for a creamy flavor.
If you'd like to make your vegetable omelette even more filling, pick a cheese that works well with the vegetables you've chosen.
Keep in mind that fresh or soft cheese melts easily into the eggs while hard cheese adds a sharp, noticeable flavor.

Use your favorite cheese or try one of these cheese and vegetable combinations:
Goat cheese with herbs or shaved asparagus
Feta with diced tomatoes and fresh onions
Cheddar with sautéed onions and peppers
Brie with sautéed mushrooms Mince fresh herbs to give the omelette a bright flavor.
It's easy to weigh down your omelette with creamy cheeses, sautéed vegetables, and leafy greens.
To add a fresh taste, mince 1 to 2 tablespoons (2 to 4 g) of your favorite herb or use a combination.

Consider using:
Chives
Parsley
Basil
Dill
Thyme
Cilantro Assembling and Serving the Omelette Place your fillings over 1/2 of the eggs in the skillet.
Spread enough sautéed or fresh vegetables to cover 1/2 of the omelette.
For example, you might only need 1/4 cup (55 g) of mushrooms with a few leafy greens.
Add cheese if you like.
Spreading the fillings over 1 side of the omelette will make it easier to flip since you won't have to worry about fillings falling out.
Fold 1/2 of the eggs over the filling to form the omelette.
Use a flat spatula to loosen the edge along 1/2 of the omelette.
Slide the spatula under the omelette and then quickly, but gently, fold the omelette over the fillings.
Then, tilt the skillet to help the omelette slide onto your plate.
If you're having trouble sliding the omelette, you may need to use the spatula to push it onto the plate.
Top the omelette with fresh vegetables.
To add even more nutrients, flavor, and texture to your omelette, slice a ripe avocado and spread it over the top.

You can also scatter baby greens, more herbs, or diced tomatoes to make the omelette even more colorful.Tip: If you don't have ripe avocado, spoon a little guacamole off to the side to get a similar flavor.
If fresh corn is in season, cut the kernels off of the cob and sprinkle them over the omelette to give it a slightly sweet flavor.
Drizzle the omelette with sauce or sprinkle seasoning over it to add flavor.
Take your omelette to the next level by topping it with some of your favorite sauces.
You could season a bell pepper omelette with creole spices, for instance.
Try adding pesto, which pairs well with mushrooms and onions or add a little sour cream or hot sauce to the veggie omelette.
For a really hearty omelette, spoon some veggie chili to the side and put cheddar cheese with sour cream on top.
